text: created by the sensory ethnography lab
at Harvard Leviathan is a nonfiction
film set on a fishing boat which avoids
the standard equipment of interviews
analysis and explanation in his review
AO Scott writes Leviathan offers not
information but immersion the experience
is often unnerving and sometimes
nauseating because the motions of the
juddering swaying hand-held camera and
also because of the distended eyes
gaping mouths and mutilated flesh of the
catch there are also passages of
abstraction that are both beguiling and
disorienting in which it becomes
difficult to distinguish big from small
natural from mechanical the film is
committed above all to capturing the
profound strangeness of an ancient and
embattled way of existence for man and
fish
